aliases: William Shakespeare
English playwright, poet, and actor born in Stratford-upon-Avon in 1564
The most famous and influential playwright in the English language, and considered by many to be the greatest dramatist of all time
Author of numerous plays and sonnets, including Romeo and Juliet, Hamlet, and Macbeth
Master of language and character, whose works explore universal themes such as love, power, and jealousy
A figurehead of the Renaissance, whose plays epitomize the era's artistic and intellectual achievements
A famous historical figure, an influential in the development of modern English literature and culture
The Bard of Avon, whose plays and sonnets are considered cornerstones of the Western literary canon
One of the most quoted and widely studied authors in history of Renaissance, whose authorship of the plays and sonnets is still debated
A writer whose legacy has had a profound impact on literature, theater, and popular culture
A towering figure in the history of English literature, whose plays and sonnets continue to be performed and read around the world
entities.description: William Shakespeare was an English playwright, poet, and actor born in Stratford-upon-Avon in 1564. He is considered the most famous and influential playwright in the English language, and the greatest dramatist of all time by many. Shakespeare's works, including Romeo and Juliet, Hamlet, and Macbeth, are masterpieces of language and character, exploring universal themes such as love, power, and jealousy. His plays epitomize the artistic and intellectual achievements of the Renaissance, and his influence on modern English literature and culture is immeasurable. Shakespeare, also known as the Bard of Avon, is one of the most quoted and widely studied authors in history. His legacy has had a profound impact on literature, theater, and popular culture, and his plays and sonnets continue to be performed and read around the world, making him a towering figure in the history of English literature. His authorship of the plays and sonnets is still debated, but he is widely regarded as the greatest writer in the English language.

aliases: Albert Einstein
Theoretical physicist born in Ulm, Germany in 1879
The creator of the theory of relativity and the famous equation E=mc²
One of the most influential scientists of the 20th century
Nobel laureate who made groundbreaking contributions to our understanding of space, time, and gravity
A genius whose ideas revolutionized modern physics and transformed our understanding of the universe
The most famous, visionary, German scientist whose work has had a profound impact on our lives, from nuclear energy to GPS technology
A figurehead of the scientific revolution of the 20th century, whose ideas continue to inspire scientists and thinkers around the world
A famous scientist, author, philosopher, and pacifist, who used his platform to advocate for peace and social justice
A towering figure in the history of science and a cultural icon, whose name has become synonymous with intelligence and creativity
One of the most recognizable and admired figures in history, whose work and legacy continue to shape our understanding of the universe
entities.description: Albert Einstein was a theoretical physicist born in Ulm, Germany in 1879, who is widely regarded as one of the most influential scientists of the 20th century. Einstein is the creator of the theory of relativity and the famous equation E=mc². He was a Nobel laureate, who made groundbreaking contributions to our understanding of space, time, and gravity. His ideas revolutionized modern physics and transformed our understanding of the universe. Einstein's work has had a profound impact on our lives, from nuclear energy to GPS technology. He is a figurehead of the scientific revolution of the 20th century, whose ideas continue to inspire scientists and thinkers around the world. In addition to his scientific achievements, Einstein was an author, philosopher, and pacifist, who used his platform to advocate for peace and social justice. Einstein is a towering figure in the history of science and a cultural icon, whose name has become synonymous with intelligence and creativity. He is one of the most recognizable and admired figures in history, whose work and legacy continue to shape our understanding of the universe.

aliases: Leonardo da Vinci
Renaissance man born in Vinci, Italy in 1452
A polymath, living in the 15th century, who is widely regarded as one of the most diversely talented individuals in history
An artist, scientist, and inventor, whose ideas anticipated many of the advancements of modern science and technology
The creator of the Mona Lisa, The Last Supper, and Vitruvian Man
A visionary artist, scientist, engineer, and inventor, who made contributions to anatomy, geology, and optics
A genius, who epitomizes the ideal of the Renaissance man, with an insatiable curiosity and an unquenchable thirst for knowledge
One of the most prominent figures of the Italian Renaissance, whose work epitomizes the era's intellectual and artistic achievements
An Italian painter, sculptor, architect, musician, mathematician, engineer, inventor, anatomist, geologist, cartographer, botanist, and writer (not Michelangelo)
The artist behind the famous painting of a woman with a mysterious smile, known as the Mona Lisa
The artist who produced Vitruvian Man, a famous drawing that depicts the ideal human proportions, based on ancient Roman architecture
entities.description: Leonardo da Vinci was a Renaissance man born in Vinci, Italy in 1452, widely regarded as one of the most diversely talented individuals in history. He was an artist, scientist, and inventor, whose ideas anticipated many of the advancements of modern science and technology. Leonardo is the creator of famous artworks such as the Mona Lisa, The Last Supper, and Vitruvian Man. He made contributions to anatomy, geology, and optics, in addition to his mastery of painting, sculpting, and architecture. Leonardo epitomizes the ideal of the Renaissance man, with an insatiable curiosity and an unquenchable thirst for knowledge. He is one of the most prominent figures of the Italian Renaissance, whose work epitomizes the era's intellectual and artistic achievements. Leonardo is an Italian painter, sculptor, architect, musician, mathematician, engineer, inventor, anatomist, geologist, cartographer, botanist, and writer. He embodies the spirit of humanism and the pursuit of knowledge, and his ideas and legacy continue to inspire generations of artists, scientists, and inventors.

aliases: Marie Curie
A Polish-born physicist and chemist who lived from 1867 to 1934
The first woman to win a Nobel Prize
Discoverer of the elements polonium and radium
A pioneer in the field of radioactivity, whose work laid the foundation for modern nuclear physics
A role model and inspiration for women in science, whose achievements opened doors for future generations of female scientists, working with her husband Pierre
A female scientist who made groundbreaking discoveries in the fields of radioactivity and nuclear physics
A Polish innovator chemist whose work has had a profound impact on modern medicine and technology
A woman who overcame discrimination and prejudice to become one of the most important scientists of the 20th century
A recipient of two Nobel Prizes, one in Physics and one in Chemistry, for her contributions to science
First woman to become the professor of physics at the University of Paris
entities.description: Marie Curie was a Polish-born physicist and chemist who lived from 1867 to 1934. She was the first woman to win a Nobel Prize and the discoverer of the elements polonium and radium. Curie was a pioneer in the field of radioactivity, whose work laid the foundation for modern nuclear physics. She is a role model and inspiration for women in science, whose achievements opened doors for future generations of female scientists. Curie was a scientist who made groundbreaking discoveries in the fields of radioactivity and nuclear physics. Her work has had a profound impact on modern medicine and technology. She overcame discrimination and prejudice to become one of the most important scientists of the 20th century. Curie is a recipient of two Nobel Prizes, one in Physics and one in Chemistry, for her contributions to science.

aliases: Ada Lovelace
A female English mathematician and writer who lived from 1815 to 1852
The world's first computer programmer
A pioneer in the field of computer science, who wrote the first algorithm intended to be processed by a machine, living up to her title as the 'Enchantress of Numbers'
A collaborator of Charles Babbage, who designed the Analytical Engine, a mechanical general-purpose computer
A woman who foresaw the potential of computers beyond mere calculation, and envisioned them as tools for creative work
A Victorian visionary, a woman credited with having a profound influence on the development of modern computing
Daughter of the poet Lord Byron, who was a famous figure in the Romantic era
A symbol of women's contributions to science and technology, and an inspiration for future generations of women in STEM fields, working on computing technology in the 19th century
A scientist collaborating with the creator of the Analytical Engine, whose work was not fully appreciated in her lifetime, but whose legacy has continued to grow in importance over time
A scientist who died at the age of 36 from cancer, considered the first programmer in history (before Alan Turing)
entities.description: Ada Lovelace was an English mathematician and writer who lived from 1815 to 1852. She is recognized as the world's first computer programmer and a pioneer in the field of computer science. Lovelace collaborated with Charles Babbage, who designed the Analytical Engine, a mechanical general-purpose computer. She wrote the first algorithm intended to be processed by a machine, and is credited with having a profound influence on the development of modern computing. Lovelace foresaw the potential of computers beyond mere calculation, and envisioned them as tools for creative work. She advocated for the application of computing technology to the arts, and for the idea that machines could augment human creativity. Lovelace is a symbol of women's contributions to science and technology, and an inspiration for future generations of women in STEM fields. Although her work was not fully appreciated in her lifetime, her legacy has continued to grow in importance over time.
